newsitem.title: YEMEN: Italian abducted in Yemen says he's treated well.
newsitem.headline: Italian abducted in Yemen says he's treated well.

text.p: An Italian tourist kidnapped by Yemeni tribesmen is in good health and negotiations for his release are proceeding well, an official at the Italian embassy in Sanaa said on Saturday.
Giorgio Bonanomi, 49, was abducted on Wednesday. A Yemeni security official said he was taken to Radaa in al-Baidha province, 150 km (93 miles) southeast of the capital Sanaa.
"We talked to the Vice Minister of Interior and he said that the negotiations are positive. But we are still waiting for news," the official told Reuters.
"We received a letter through the government from Mr Bonanomi and he said 'I am in good condition and the treatment is very good. Don't worry about me. I hope the story will be over soon,'" he said.
Bonanomi, from Lecco in northern Italy, was kidnapped less than two weeks after the abduction of two other Italians by Yemeni tribesmen.
Luigi Archetti and Maria Paola Mariconi were held as part of a property dispute with authorities but were released after one day.
Kidnapping is a common tactic by Yemeni tribes holding grievances against the government or foreign oil firms operating in Yemen, one of the Arab world's poorest countries.
Tribesmen have tried to use hostages -- who have included French and U.S. diplomats and a Saudi ambassador -- as bargaining chips in mostly land and water disputes.
In March, four German tourists were kidnapped. Earlier that month a group of seven German motorcycle tourists were also seized.
In February, a U.S. oil engineer was taken hostage by a Yemeni mountain tribe.
All hostages have been released unharmed so far.
